title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V for various functions like managing federal property and regulating financial institutions. It also covers general provisions in Title VII and Cuba sanctions in Title I. Additionally, it funds the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. Mandatory retirement accounts are funded in Title VI, with occasional additional titles addressing financial regulation. Financial regulatory agencies are funded separately from FSGG appropriations bills. The FSGG bill funds independent agencies for various functions, including financial regulation. The CFTC is funded through the FSGG bill in the Senate and the Agriculture appropriations bill in the House. President Trump's FY2018 budget requested approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies, with $330 million allocated for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported a total funding of $501 million for the FSGG independent agencies and the CFTC. The FSGG bill funds independent agencies, including the CFTC. President Trump's FY2018 budget requested $3.1 billion for independent agencies, with $330 million for the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported $501 million for FSGG independent agencies and the CFTC. H.R. 3268, H.R. 3354, and H.R. 601 were key legislative actions related to funding, with differences in funding allocations for GSA and SBA. H.R. 601 / P.L. 115-56, along with subsequent CRs, provided funding for FSGG agencies through December 8, 2017. P.L. 115-123 allocated additional funds for GSA and SBA to address hurricane disaster costs. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 1625 / P.L. 115-141) focused on human trafficking eradication and passed in March 2018. The Congressional Record for March 22, 2018, included an Explanatory Statement regarding FSGG appropriations totaling $4.7 billion for FY2018, with significant differences in funding for agencies like the SBA, GSA, FCC, and EAC. Table 1 and Table 2 provide details on the status of FSGG appropriations and the President's FY2018 request. The FSGG appropriations bill provides funding for independent agencies overseeing derivatives markets, including the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Their functions include oversight of futures and swaps markets, fraud prevention, and investor protection. Following the financial crisis of 2008, the Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction, along with regulated futures and options markets. This expanded the CFTC's oversight to include swaps markets with an estimated notional value of $240 trillion in the US, in addition to their prior jurisdiction over futures and options markets valued at $34 trillion. Congressional authorization for the CFTC remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to its historical ties to agricultural markets. Appropriations for the CFTC are under the jurisdiction of the Agriculture Appropriations Subcommittee in the House and the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Subcommittee in the Senate. The CFTC has oversight over futures and options markets with a $34 trillion notional value in the US. The President requested $250 million for the CFTC in FY2018, with appropriations varying between $248 million and $250 million. The CPSC's mission is to reduce consumer harm from various products through safety standards, recalls, and consumer education. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the CPSC in FY2018. The CPSC requested $123 million in appropriations for FY2018, $3 million less than FY2017. The reduction included cuts to the VGBPSA grant program and salaries. The budget would be allocated to four strategic goals. H.R. 3354 passed with the requested amount, including $1.3 million for new VGBPSA grants. The House Appropriations Committee's report on the bill for FY2018 CPSC appropriations included provisions to maintain grant funding levels and restrict the adoption of certain proposed rules. The bill also included provisions related to recreational off-highway vehicles and blade saws. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 appropriated $126 million. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to provide grant funding to states. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 (HAVA) to provide grant funding to states for election reform programs, testing and certifying voting machines, and publishing studies of election issues. The EAC does not have new rulemaking authority under HAVA, but it took over responsibilities for the National Voter Registration Act (NVRA) from the Federal Election Commission (FEC). The Department of Justice enforces HAVA. The President's budget request for FY2018 included $9.2 million for the EAC, with $1.5 million allocated to the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) for testing guidelines for voting systems. The House and Senate proposed different funding amounts for the EAC, with the final appropriation being $10.1 million, including $1.5 million for NIST. The EAC received $10.1 million in appropriations, with $1.5 million to be transferred to NIST. Additionally, $380 million was allocated for improving election administration. The FCC, an independent agency, regulates communications and operates on fees collected from license holders. For FY2018, the FCC requested a budget of $322 million, all from regulatory fees, $34.5 million less than the previous year. The FCC requested $322 million for FY2018, $34.5 million less than the previous year. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General received $39.1 million in appropriations, an increase from FY2017. The FEC is an independent agency that administers... The FEC is an independent agency that enforces campaign finance regulations and administers the presidential public financing system. For FY2018, the agency requested $71.25 million, with approximately 90% of the budget allocated for salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. The appropriations for the FEC have generally been noncontroversial, with recent funding including an additional $7.9 million for office space relocation. The House-passed version of the FSGG legislation included provisions related to campaign finance policy, such as prohibiting the SEC from issuing rules on disclosure of political contributions and limiting government-contracting processes. The FTC's primary responsibilities are to protect consumers from deceptive business practices. The FTC's primary responsibilities are to protect consumers from deceptive or illegal business practices and to maintain competition in various industries. It enforces laws, issues regulations, and educates consumers and businesses. The agency's operating funds come from direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. In FY2017, the FTC's budget was $313.0 million, with direct appropriations accounting for 53.3%, HSR filing fees for 41.8%, and DNC registry fees for 5.0%. The President's FY2018 request proposed a budget of $306.3 million, $6.7 million less than FY2017, with cuts in various areas. The House Appropriations Committee directed the FTC to submit reports on enforcing privacy laws and consumer benefits of credit education services. The Senate draft bill proposed $306.3 million for the FTC in FY2018. The FTC has been appropriated $306.3 million, with funding sources including direct appropriations, HSR filing fees, and DNC registry fees. The General Services Administration oversees federal procurement policies, property disposal, and management, funded through the Federal Buildings Fund. This fund receives rental payments from federal agencies for various activities like construction, repairs, and rental payments. The General Services Administration's Federal Buildings Fund (FBF) has limitations on funds obligated by Congress, which can be used for certain debts. A negative total in the FBF indicates a net gain under proposed spending levels. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately from the FBF, with total funding calculated by combining FBF appropriations and operating account appropriations. The President's FY2018 request proposed a limit of $9.951 billion from the FBF's available revenue for GSA's real property. The President proposed a limit of $9.951 billion from the FBF's available revenue for GSA's real property activities for FY2018, an increase of $1.106 billion above the amount provided in FY2017. P.L. 115-141 provided a limit of $9.074 billion, an increase of $229 million above the amount provided for FY2017. The President also requested $511 million for GSA's operating accounts, including $40 million for the newly created Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund. The President's request for FY2018 included funding for new accounts such as the Environmental Review Improvement Fund and the Technology Modernization Fund. The House-passed bill allocated $240 million for GSA's operating accounts, while the Senate draft bill provided $234 million. P.L. 115-141 ultimately provided $335 million for GSA's operating accounts. The FSGG appropriations bill for FY2018 included $81 million more than FY2017 and $176 million less than the President's request. P.L. 115-123 also included an additional $127 million in emergency supplemental GSA appropriations. The bill funds four agencies with personnel management functions: FLRA, MSPB, OPM, and OSC. FLRA administers Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. The FLRA administers Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act, granting federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively. Employees have the right not to join a union representing employees in their bargaining unit. Specific agencies are excluded by law, with the President having the authority to exclude others for national security reasons. The FLRA is composed of a three-member authority, the Office of General Counsel, and the FSIP, resolving disputes over bargaining units, unfair labor practices, and representation elections. The General Counsel's office manages representation elections, investigates unfair labor practices, and oversees regional offices. The FLRA manages regional offices and the FSIP resolves labor negotiation impasses. The President requested $26.2 million for the FLRA in FY2018, funding 121 FTEs. The MSPB, an independent agency, adjudicates appeals involving personnel actions and retirement benefits. The President requested $46.8 million for the MSPB in FY2018, funding 235 FTEs. The President's budget requested $46.8 million for the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) in FY2018, including funding for IT infrastructure modernization and Trust Fund Federal Financial System migration. OPM also requested appropriations for trust fund transfers, OIG salaries and expenses, and acquisition workforce capacity strengthening. The budget included an FTE employment level of 6,376 for FY2018. OPM requested an increase in FTE employment level for FY2018 to address critical IT infrastructure needs and maintain security posture. The budget will support OIG oversight activities, including audits, investigations, and evaluations of various OPM programs. Additionally, funding will advance prescription drug audit and FEHBP claims data warehouse initiatives. The OIG will provide oversight for the agency's IT infrastructure project, including data center consolidation and potential mainframe migrations. The House passed appropriations of $129.3 million for these purposes. The House and Senate draft bill allocated appropriations for OPM salaries and expenses, trust fund transfers, and OIG salaries and expenses. The amounts were the same as the President's request except for OPM salaries and expenses, which were $19 million less. H.R. 3354 required a report evaluating OPM's cybersecurity measures to be submitted within six months of enactment. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize retirement processing and move to a fully-automated electronic filing system. They also instructed OPM to enhance IT security measures and expedite security clearance investigations. Additionally, OPM was directed to provide biannual progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan. The OPM OIG must submit a report assessing the implementation of NBIB, staffing needs, costs, governance structure, and recommendations. OPM is reminded to prioritize critical functions like recruitment and report on reducing barriers to Federal employment. The House committee directed OPM to increase recruitment efforts at Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities, review GAO recommendations on hiring authorities, and provide resources to federal agencies for critical positions. OPM was also directed to report on actions to improve hiring of CyberCorps graduates and acquisition planning within 90 days of the act's enactment. OPM is directed to brief the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations within six months on actions taken to improve information security. OPM must also provide updates on modernization efforts, retirement backlog, and mandatory appropriations for health benefits and retirement accounts. The Congressional Budget Office estimated funding for various government payments and the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) requested $26.5 million for FY2018 appropriations to protect federal employees from prohibited personnel practices. The agency projected stable trends in whistleblower cases and requested funding to meet rising demand for its services. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) is an independent agency created to preserve government records and make them publicly available. The agency requested $376 million for FY2018, with the House passing $380 million and the Senate proposing $403 million. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) is funded by credit unions and manages the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund. The NCUA oversees the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to support low-income credit unions in offering financial services to low-income communities. The CDRLF provides low-interest loans, deposits, and technical assistance grants. Funding for the CDRLF was $2 million in FY2018, with the President initially requesting no appropriation. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent agency responsible for financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics regulations. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) oversees financial disclosure, conflict of interest, and ethics regulations in the executive branch. OGE is headed by a director appointed by the President for a five-year term with Senate confirmation. It provides education and training to ethics officials but does not investigate or prosecute ethics violations. The President's FY2018 request for OGE was $16.4 million, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-141. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency within the executive branch in 2007. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was reconstituted as an independent agency in 2007 with its first funding. The board's responsibilities include ensuring privacy and civil liberties concerns are considered in anti-terrorism efforts, reviewing implementation of related laws and policies, advising the President and executive branch, and providing annual reports to Congress. The President requested $8 million for PCLOB in FY2018, compared to $10.1 million in FY2017. The PCLOB was appropriated $8 million in FY2017. The PCAOB, created by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, is funded through accounting support fees. A scholarship program for accounting students is funded by penalties imposed by the PCAOB. The Senate draft bill proposed using funds collected by the Board for scholarships. The SEC administers federal securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair trading markets. The agency's budget is funded through fees collected from securities exchanges. The President's FY2018 request for the SEC was $1.85 billion, compared to $1.61 billion in FY2017. $1 million was allocated for scholarships in FY2017, but no funding was included in the FY2018 request. P.L. 115-141 specified that not more than $1 million should be spent on scholarships. The SEC's budget for FY2018 totaled $1.85 billion, an increase from the previous year. The Dodd-Frank Act established a reserve fund for the SEC, funded by registration fees, to cover long-term expenses. The President's request for FY2018 included rescinding $25 million from the reserve fund, while the House proposed rescinding $75 million. The Senate draft bill did not include any rescinding of funds from the reserve. The SEC's budget for FY2018 was $1.85 billion, with $1.90 billion appropriated for FY2019, offset by fee collections. The Selective Service System (SSS) is an independent federal agency that registers males aged 18-25 for potential military conscription. The draft ended in 1973, but standby draft registration for both men and women was approved in 1980. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but decreased in inflation-adjusted terms. The Small Business Administration (SBA) administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees, low-interest loans for disaster victims, training programs, and advocacy. The President requested $829.1 million for the SBA in FY2018, $57.6 million less than FY2017. Funding allocation included $265.0 million for salaries, $192.5 million for development programs, $152.8 million for loan administration, $3.4 million for loan subsidies, and $19.9 million for the Inspector General's office. The Administration requested funding for various SBA programs including business loan subsidies, the Office of the Inspector General, disaster assistance, and loan guaranty programs. The House-passed bill appropriated $862.8 million for the SBA in FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, and noncredit programs. Additionally, Microloan intermediaries were allowed to spend up to 50% of their technical assistance grant funds on prospective activities. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended allocating $886.3 million for the SBA in FY2018, with $269.5 million for salaries and expenses and $245.1 million for entrepreneurial development. The final appropriation in P.L. 115-141 was $700.8 million, with no funding for disaster assistance due to previous allocations for hurricane costs. The SBA received $1.66 billion in funding, mainly for disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The USPS generates revenue by charging for services, with Congress providing appropriations for revenue forgone for free mailing privileges. Additionally, USPS receives a $29 million annual reimbursement until 2035 for below-cost postal services. The Postal Service Fund is a revolving fund used to pay operating expenses for USPS, USPSOIG, and PRC. The PAEA law affects postal appropriations, requiring USPSOIG and PRC to submit budget requests to Congress and OMB. The President's FY2018 budget requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund and $71.3 million for USPS, an increase from FY2017. The USPSOIG requested $71.3 million for FY2018, an increase of $36.7 million from FY2017. The President requested $234.7 million for USPSOIG, $19 million less than FY2017. The PRC requested $14.4 million for FY2018, $1.8 million less than FY2017. The House-passed bill included long-standing postal policy provisions such as maintaining six-day mail delivery, providing free mail for overseas voting and the blind, and prohibiting fees for child support agencies seeking addresses. The President's FY2018 budget proposed similar policies but not for six-day mail delivery. The Trump Administration suggested cost-reducing reforms like adjusting mail delivery frequency and transitioning to centralized delivery. The Administration proposed reforms to USPS, including centralized mail delivery and adjusting rate structures for financial stability. The President's FY2018 budget aimed to reduce the budget deficit by $46 billion over 10 years through changes in retirement and health benefit liabilities. P.L. 115-141 incorporated some House-passed provisions but did not enact further reforms as requested by the President. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters. It was appropriated $51.2 million in FY2017, with varying amounts requested and appropriated in subsequent years. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes general provisions that are not made permanent. The Administration's proposed government-wide general provisions for a fiscal year are typically included in the Budget Appendix. The FY2018 budget proposal includes adjustments to discretionary spending limits based on estimating differences with CBO. The DACA program allows aliens to be employed in the US. The Treasury Department's OFAC administers Cuba embargo regulations. H.R. 3280 had provisions to tighten US economic sanctions on Cuba. The FY2018 budget proposal included provisions in H.R. 3280 to tighten U.S. economic sanctions on Cuba, but two key provisions were not included in the final legislation. Section 130 aimed to restrict the importation of rum and tobacco products confiscated by the Cuban government, while Section 131 related to trademark sanctions on Cuba. These provisions would have limited the authorization of licenses for confiscated assets unless the original owner consented. The provision in the FY2018 budget proposal aimed to restrict trademark sanctions on Cuba, specifically related to the Havana Club trademark dispute with Bacardi Limited. OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to renew the trademark, which was subsequently renewed until 2026 by the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office. The provision was not included in the final appropriations measure.
